Partial fraction decomposition.......prepare them for Calc 2 where not knowing PFD can be a major hurdle that is difficult to overcome. Another is remembering how to find the roots of nth term polynomials. Comes in Calc 3 when you need to find extrema in R3 and you need to find the zeros of your boundary lines and boundary intersection points; imagine needing this on an exam when your partial derivative is a cubic. I just had that on my Exam 3 for Calc 3 and it was a huge stumbling point for me. Remembering how to find the factors of the leading and trailing coefficients to find a polymonial factor and then do polynomial long division to find the rest. Very very tough because you really don't do things like that for several years and it gets forgotten. Also, completing the square is pivotal in Calc 3 and DiffEq and many are blindsided by it.

It sounds like a great idea, honestly. I probably won't be able to watch it live, since I have quite a bit to do for college - I'm studying math - but I'll be sure to check it out when I can.

About math being more about paper and pencil, I disagree. While those are pretty good tools, I think the development of technology, and the consequent increase in quality and quantity of tools to do math, allows for people to focus more on the theory, and even for development, while letting the computer do the demonstrations.
For instance, a few days ago I made a function that draws the tangent of any given point of a polynomial function. The function itself is kinda big, and it requires a lot of calculations, not to mention some of the process was more trial and error - just a couple tweaks. It was tedious and frustrating. Having to manually draw the function for several points just to check it worked, for multiple polynomials, that would've been so much extra work had I not used a graphing calculator.

Point is, sometimes letting a computer do the computing is better for you to focus on the math.

I noticed something weird with the frame pacing of this video, even though Youtube says it's 60hz, you can obviously tell it isn't just by watching at it.
So I took some time to count how many 60Hz frames each original frame is shown by going through frame by frame using the '.>' key.
This is the raw data:
|---|----|--|--|----|--|--|----|--|--|--|----|----|--|--|----|--|--|--|--|----|--|----|--|--|--|----|----|--|--|--|----|--|----|--|--|--|----|--|--|--|----|--|--|--|----|--|--|--|----|--|--|--|----|--|--|----|--|--|--|---- (I stopped here cause i got tired)
Converted to numbers:
3,4,2,2,4,2,2,4,2,2,2,4,4,2,2,4,2,2,2,2,4,2,4,2,2,2,4,4,2,2,2,4,2,4,2,2,2,4,2,2,2,4,2,2,2,4,2,2,2,4,2,2,2,4,2,2,4,2,2,2,4...


If you multiply each number with 1/60th of a second you get the duration of each frame.
I just can't see any pattern in this, it seems very random but there are some short bursts of stability.
The weirdest thing about this, is that there are only 2's and 4's (excluding the first 3).


Normally when you convert from one frame rate to another non-integer multiple, you get 2 consecutive numbers, like when you watch a 24Hz movie (I'm aware it's actually 23.976Hz) on a 60Hz monitor (without motion smoothing) you get 2,3,2,3... instead of e.g. 1,4,1,4... because 2 and 3 are closer and gives a more even frame pacing, which is smoother.
Every group of 2 and 4 could be converted to 3's and the video would be much smoother.
The only thing I can think of that would explain this, is that the video has been converted to many different frame rates along the editing process e.g. 24Hz->30Hz->60Hz or something similar.
I also noticed that the ending animation and the fade between the different takes is at 60Hz but not the fade to the pen and paper.
I'm very curious how this happened and would greatly appreciate any answers that may give some insight to this.

The way I usually do the ax² + bx + c = 0 nowadays is to divide out the a first so I start with x² + dx + e = 0 --> (x+½d)² - ¼d² + e = 0, which already seams less convoluted than the normal abc formula, but when actually using it it's even more obvious.  Applying the formula, if you've memorized it well, is probably faster, but this is more intuitive to me.  By the way, if you work that out, you get the abc formula. Loh's method is amazing. When I learned about it, I imagined how I would teach it to high schoolers and I got really excited!

I imagined it like this:
First teach about solving quadratic evolutions by factoring. Using the knowledge of how the factors of a quadratic equation multiply to get the whole thing, introduce completing the square. Then generalize completing the square to get the quadratic formula. Now with the knowledge that the two solutions of the equation are equal distances from the vertex of the parabola gained from the quadratic formula, introduce Loh's method.

I like this because it slowly builds up to loh's method so students can fully understand why it works.

After learning 2ODE I realised how impractical the quadratic formula is. Why are there 3 parameters in an equation that can be described by 2?? Why aren't more schools teaching how to get to the equation? I mean there are multiple very simple ways to do it! You can translate y = x^2 in x and y, you can also solve it purely algebraically but without the useless 3rd parameter and it is also really simple. So many ways... and we are stuck with this cumbersome formula... Also I personally would put a 2 in front of the 1st power of x (maybe even -2) so that there are only parameters in the final answer. But that's just details.
